text: So the heathen shall fear the name of the LORD, and all the kings of the earth thy glory.
text_kjv: So the heathen shall fear the name of the LORD, and all the kings of the earth thy glory.
text_niv: The nations will fear the name of the Lord,all the kings of the earth will revere your glory.
text_esv: Nations will fear the name of the LORD, and all the kings of the earth will fear your glory.
text_nlt: Then the nations will tremble before the LORD.The kings of the earth will tremble before his glory.
text_msg: The godless nations will sit up and take notice—see your glory, worship your name—
text_nasb: So the nations will fear the name of the LORD And all the kings of the earth Your glory.
context: Psalm 102 is a prayer of an afflicted person, likely experiencing exile or severe hardship. Its composition likely dates to the post-exilic period, after the Babylonian exile when the temple lay in ruins and the Jewish people struggled to rebuild their nation and faith. The 'heathen' in verse 15 refers to the surrounding nations, many of whom had witnessed the destruction of Jerusalem and the perceived failure of Yahweh to protect His people. These nations, often polytheistic, worshipped a multitude of gods and likely saw Israel's defeat as proof of their own gods' superiority. 'Kings of the earth' would represent the rulers of those nations, holding significant political and military power. During this period, the political landscape was complex, with empires vying for control and exerting pressure on smaller nations like Judah. The Psalmist's hope expressed here is rooted in a belief that God will ultimately restore Zion, not just for the sake of Israel, but to demonstrate His power and glory to the entire world. The rebuilding of the temple would be a tangible sign of God's faithfulness and power. The expectation was that this restoration would inspire awe and reverence in the surrounding nations, leading them to acknowledge Yahweh as the one true God. This acknowledgment would also serve as a powerful witness, drawing them to consider the truth of Israel's faith.
meaning: Verse 15, 'So the heathen shall fear the name of the LORD, and all the kings of the earth thy glory,' expresses a prophetic hope for the universal recognition of God's sovereignty. The 'fear of the LORD' is not mere terror, but a profound reverence, respect, and awe born from acknowledging His power, holiness, and justice. It is a recognition of God's supreme authority and a desire to align oneself with His will. The use of 'name' is significant, as in Hebrew thought, the name represents the essence and character of the person. To fear the name of the Lord is to fear and respect who He is. The phrase 'all the kings of the earth thy glory' indicates that this acknowledgment of God's glory would extend to the highest levels of earthly power. 'Glory' refers to God's manifest presence, His power, majesty, and splendor. It is the visible or perceivable evidence of His divine nature. The verse suggests that God's actions in restoring Zion would be so powerful and evident that even the most powerful rulers would be compelled to recognize His glory. This verse echoes similar prophecies found throughout the Old Testament (Isaiah 2:2-4, Micah 4:1-5) that point towards a future when all nations will acknowledge Yahweh. It highlights the universal scope of God's plan of salvation and His desire to be known and worshiped by all people. It suggests that Israel's restoration is not simply a national event, but a catalyst for global transformation, leading to the recognition of God's sovereignty and glory.
application: Psalm 102:15 challenges us to consider our role in making God's glory known to the nations today. We are called to live lives that reflect God's character and attract others to Him. This can be done through acts of service, displays of compassion, and consistent witness of our faith. Just as the rebuilding of the temple was meant to be a sign to the surrounding nations, our lives should be living testimonies of God's grace and power. Consider how your actions, words, and attitudes might influence those around you, particularly those who do not yet know Christ. Are you embodying Christ's love and compassion in your interactions with others? We are called to actively share the gospel, both verbally and through our actions. This requires intentionality and a willingness to step outside of our comfort zones. Pray for opportunities to share your faith and for the courage to speak truth in love. The phrase 'kings of the earth' reminds us that we should also pray for those in positions of authority, both locally and globally. Pray that they would be open to God's guidance and that their decisions would align with His will. We should advocate for justice and righteousness in our communities and nations, working to create a society that reflects God's kingdom. Remember that God's ultimate goal is for all people to come to know and worship Him. This verse calls us to be active participants in that mission, living our lives in a way that points others to the glory of God. We must not only pray for the nations, but actively seek opportunities to share the love and truth of the Gospel with those who have yet to hear. This could involve supporting missionaries, participating in short-term mission trips, or simply sharing your faith with your neighbors and colleagues. Seek God's guidance and ask Him to show you how you can contribute to His global mission.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for your promise that one day all nations will acknowledge your glory. We confess that we often fall short in reflecting your light to the world. Forgive us for our apathy and lack of boldness in sharing the good news of Jesus Christ. Fill us with your Holy Spirit and empower us to be witnesses of your love and grace. Give us wisdom to discern opportunities to share our faith and courage to speak your truth in love. We pray for those in positions of authority, that their hearts would be open to your guidance and that their decisions would reflect your justice and righteousness. Use us, Lord, as instruments of your peace and agents of your kingdom. May our lives be living testimonies of your glory, drawing others to you. Help us to actively participate in your global mission, both through our prayers and our actions. We lift up the nations to you, asking that you would break down barriers and open hearts to receive your gospel. May the day come soon when all people, from the least to the greatest, will fear your name and give glory to you. In Jesus' name we pray, Amen.

faqs.answer: The focus on 'heathen' and 'kings' emphasizes the universality of God's intended reach. 'Heathen' represents the general populace of other nations, while 'kings' represent their leaders. The inclusion of both indicates that everyone, regardless of social status or national origin, will ultimately recognize God's glory and sovereignty.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: Why does the Psalm focus on 'heathen' and 'kings'?

faqs.answer: Psalm 102:15 foreshadows the Great Commission (Matthew 28:19-20), where Jesus commands his followers to go and make disciples of all nations. It highlights the same ultimate goal: the spread of God's glory and the acknowledgement of His name among all peoples.
faqs.question: Q2: How does this verse connect to the Great Commission in the New Testament?

faqs.answer: The 'fear of the LORD' is a positive concept. It's not merely being afraid of God, but a deep reverence, respect, and awe that leads to obedience and a desire to please Him. It’s a recognition of His power and holiness.
faqs.question: Q3: Is the 'fear of the LORD' a negative or positive concept?

faqs.answer: To glorify God means to make His attributes and character known and appreciated. It involves living a life that reflects His goodness, love, justice, and holiness, bringing honor and praise to His name through our words and actions.
faqs.question: Q4: What does it mean to glorify God?

faqs.answer: You can apply this verse by being a person of integrity, showing kindness and compassion to your colleagues or classmates, and using opportunities to share your faith respectfully and authentically. Be a light that shines for Christ where you are.
